title: Causes and Consequences of Labor Market Flexibility
descriptions:
Here is a 299-word abstract for the grant proposal:

Title: Causes and Consequences of Labor Market Flexibility (LABFLEX)

The proposed project, LABFLEX, aims to investigate the causes and consequences of labor market flexibility, a pressing issue in the face of globalization, technological change, and workplace transformation. The rise of outsourcing, sub-contracting, flexible scheduling, and flexible pay jobs has sparked concerns about wage inequality and the division of resources in society. This project seeks to provide new evidence on the drivers and outcomes of labor market flexibility, with a focus on the organization of labor and its impact on workers and firms.

The objectives of LABFLEX are to examine the causes and consequences of labor market flexibility, with a particular emphasis on the role of job contract differences, technology advances, and labor market institutions. The project will employ a multi-method approach, combining register data, experimental evidence on worker preferences, and analysis of full-text corpus of vacancies with job attribute information. This innovative approach will allow us to address key questions, including whether job contract differences reflect worker preferences or technology advances, and how labor market flexibility affects wage inequality, gender wage gaps, and the distribution of resources.

The expected outcomes of LABFLEX include a comprehensive understanding of the supply and demand sides of the labor market, shedding light on the complex relationships between labor market flexibility, worker preferences, and firm behavior. The project's findings will inform labor market policies and contribute to a more equitable distribution of resources in society. By providing new insights into the causes and consequences of labor market flexibility, LABFLEX has the potential to make a significant impact on our understanding of the modern labor market.

Ultimately, the project will enhance our understanding of the complex dynamics driving labor market flexibility and its implications for workers, firms, and society as a whole.
